[[Günther Beck von Mannagetta und Lerchenau|Beck]] (1923) }} '''''Gyroporus castaneus''''', or commonly the '''chestnut bolete''', is a small, white-pored relation of the ''[[Boletus]]'' mushrooms. It has a brown [[pileus (mycology)|cap]], and is usually found with [[oak]] trees. It differs from the true boletes in that the [[spore]]s are a pale straw colour. == Taxonomy == The species was described initially by the French mycologist [[Jean Baptiste François Pierre Bulliard]] (1742–1792). Formerly a member of the [[Paxillaceae]] [[family (biology)|family]], research now places this mushroom in [[Gyroporaceae]]. ''Gyroporus'' means 'having round pores', and ''castaneus'' is a reference to the chestnut colouration. == Description == The [[Pileus (mycology)|cap]] is from 3 to 10 cm in diameter, and pale to rusty brown in colour, which becomes darker with age. The [[Stipe (mycology)|stem]] is a similar colour, although it may be lighter at the apex. If the stem is cut vertically, it is usual to find several cavities of differing sizes inside. Both the cap and the stem have a tendency to crack or split in dry periods, or with age. The pores are small and white; they become dirtier with age, and are not attached to the stem. They darken slightly when pressed. The tubes are also whitish, and the spore print is pale yellow to straw. The [[trama (mycology)|flesh]] is firm,{{cite book | author = Roger Phillips | year = 2006 | title = Mushrooms | publisher = Pan MacMillan | isbn = 0-330-44237-6}} and does not change colour on cutting. The photograph on the right shows the chunkier form; a slender form also occurs. [[File:Gyro.cav (2).jpg|right|thumb|190px|Illustration of typical stem cavities in ''G. castaneus'']] == Distribution and habitat == The mushroom is found occasionally in Britain and throughout continental Europe, as well as eastern North America, but it is rare in western North America.{{cite book |author=David Arora |year=1986 |title=Mushrooms Demystified |publisher=Ten Speed Press |isbn=0-89815-169-4 |url-access=registration |url=https://archive.org/details/mushroomsdemysti00aror_0 }} It grows in small groups, or singly, in an [[mycorrhiza|ectomycorrhizal]] relationship with oaks (''[[Quercus]]''). It prefers acid and sandy soils, and fruits from summer to autumn. In New Zealand, it is found in association with ''[[Leptospermum]]''.{{cite journal |author=McNabb RFR. |title=The Boletaceae of New Zealand |journal=New Zealand Journal of Botany |year=1968 |volume=6 |issue=2 |pages=137–76 (see p. 166) |doi=10.1080/0028825X.1968.10429056}} {{open access}} In Asia, it has been recorded from Taiwan. ''Gyroporus castaneus'' has been included in the [[Moscow Oblast]]'s and the [[Russian Federation]]'s [[Red Data Book of the Russian Federation|Red Book]] and several other countries' Red Lists, including those of [[Norway]] and [[Montenegro]].{{cite web | title=Каштановий Гриб | publisher=Red Book of Moscow Oblast | url=http://www.geogr.msu.ru/rb/rb/fungi/gyroporus_castaneus.html | accessdate=September 5, 2008 |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20080517071908/http://www.geogr.msu.ru/rb/rb/fungi/gyroporus_castaneus.html |archivedate = May 17, 2008}}{{cite web | title=The Provisory Red List of Endangered Macromycetes of Montenegro | publisher= Montenegrin Mycological Center | url=http://www.wsl.ch/eccf/Montenegro05.pdf |format=PDF| accessdate=September 5, 2008}}{{cite web | title=Red List of Threatened Fungi in Norway | publisher= Fungiflora 1998 | url=http://www.nhm.uio.no/botanisk/sopp/redintro_gammel.htm | accessdate=September 5, 2008 }} == Edibility == {{mycomorphbox | name =''Gyroporus castaneus'' | capShape = convex | capShape2=flat | hymeniumType=pores | stipeCharacter=bare | ecologicalType=mycorrhizal | sporePrintColor=yellow | howEdible=edible }} ''Gyroporus castaneus'' is [[edible mushroom|edible]], and highly regarded by most authors; it is said to taste pleasantly nutty when young.{{citation needed|date=March 2018}} However, Marcel Bon, in his 1987 book ''The Mushrooms and Toadstools of Britain and North Western Europe'', records it as suspect,{{cite book | author = Marcel Bon | year = 1987 | title = The Mushrooms and Toadstools of Britain and North Western Europe | publisher = Hodder and Stoughton | isbn = 0-340-39935-X}} so it may be worth applying caution, by eating a very small amount initially. There is also reportedly a [[poisonous mushroom|poisonous]] strain of this mushroom in coastal Portugal.{{cite book | author = Thomas Laessoe | year = 1998 | title = Mushrooms (flexi bound) | publisher = Dorling Kindersley | isbn = 0-7513-1070-0}} ==See also== *[[List of North American boletes]] ==References== {{Reflist|refs= {{cite journal |author=Yeh K-W, Chen Z-C. |title=The boletes of Taiwan |journal=Taiwania |year=1980 |volume=25 |issue=1 |pages=166–184 |url=http://tai2.ntu.edu.tw/taiwania/pdf/tai.1980.25.166.pdf}} }} ==External links== {{Commons category}} {{Taxonbar|from=Q1165913}} [[Category:Edible fungi]] [[Category:Boletales]] [[Category:Fungi described in 1787]] [[Category:Fungi of Asia]] [[Category:Fungi of Europe]] [[Category:Fungi of New Zealand]] [[Category:Fungi of North America]]
